data.name: Polygonal Numbers
data.description:
## Challenge
A number of equally spaced points that can be arranged to form a regular polygon is termed *polygonal*. Your solution will accept two arguments:
1. `string shape`, which will always be "**triangle**", "**square**", "**pentagon**" or "**hexagon**";
2. and `int n`.

Return the *nth* number of the requested *shape*. For instance, `Polygon.IterateShape("triangle", 3)` must return the third triangular number: 6. (For the sake of this exercise, the first number of each shape is 1.)

If `n == 0`, return 0.

If `n < 0`, return -1.

If `n > -1` but `shape` is not equal to one of the four accepted strings, return -2.
## Triangular Numbers
    1         3           6             10              15                21                  28
    O         O O         O O O         O O O O         O O O O O         O O O O O O         O O O O O O O
               O           O O           O O O           O O O O           O O O O O           O O O O O O
                            O             O O             O O O             O O O O             O O O O O
                                           O               O O               O O O               O O O O
                                                            O                 O O                 O O O
                                                                               O                   O O
                                                                                                    O
If a particular number of equally spaced dots can form an equilateral triangle, that number may be called triangular.
## Square Numbers
    1        4          9            16             25               36                 49
    O        O O        O O O        O O O O        O O O O O        O O O O O O        O O O O O O O
             O O        O O O        O O O O        O O O O O        O O O O O O        O O O O O O O
                        O O O        O O O O        O O O O O        O O O O O O        O O O O O O O
                                     O O O O        O O O O O        O O O O O O        O O O O O O O
                                                    O O O O O        O O O O O O        O O O O O O O
                                                                     O O O O O O        O O O O O O O
                                                                                        O O O O O O O
A number of equally spaced dots that may form a square is a square number.
## Pentagonal Numbers
    1       5             12               22                   35                      51
    O         O O           O O O             O O O O               O O O O O                O O O O O O
             O   O         O O   O           O O O   O             O O O O   O              O O O O O   O
               O          O   O   O         O O   O   O           O O O   O   O            O O O O   O   O
                            O   O          O   O   O   O         O O   O   O   O          O O O   O   O   O
                              O              O   O   O          O   O   O   O   O        O O   O   O   O   O
                                               O   O              O   O   O   O         O   O   O   O   O   O
                                                 O                  O   O   O             O   O   O   O   O
                                                                      O   O                 O   O   O   O
                                                                        O                     O   O   O
                                                                                                O   O
                                                                                                  O
A pentagonal number is to a pentagon that which a triangular number and a square number are to a triangle and a square, respectively. Unlike the first two concepts, a visual representation of a pentagonal number cannot be rotationally symmetrical. In the above diagram the leftmost vertex is shared.
## Hexagonal Numbers
    1        6              15                   28                         45
    O          O O              O O O                  O O O O                      O O O O O
             O     O          O       O              O         O                  O           O
               O O          O   O O     O          O   O O O     O              O   O O O O     O
                              O     O O          O   O       O     O          O   O         O     O
                                O O O              O   O O     O O          O   O   O O O     O     O
                                                     O     O O O              O   O       O     O O
                                                       O O O O                  O   O O     O O O
                                                                                  O     O O O O
                                                                                    O O O O O
Beginning with 1, every other [triangular number](#triangular-numbers) is a hexagonal number. The above illustrates that a hexagonal number is one in which that number of dots form the outline(s) of regular hexagons where all hexagons share a single vertex. In the above diagram the bottom-left vertex is shared.

|n              |1              |2              |3              |4              |5              |6              |7              |
|:-------------:|:-------------:|:-------------:|:-------------:|:-------------:|:-------------:|:-------------:|:-------------:|
|Triangles      |1              |3              |**6**          |10             |**15**         |21             |**28**         |
|Hexagons       |1              |**6**          |**15**         |**28**         |45             |66             |91             |

*Table 1: A visual aid to deduce the relationship between triangular and hexagonal numbers with respect to n.*
